pr_title: [PLANNER-1867] Add JSONB support for Score JSON in optaplanner-persistence-jsonb

timeline.bodyText: Did you consider using JsonbAdapter? It would bring the serializer and deserializer under one roof, and from what I've seen in this PR, you don't need the advanced access to parser that the deserializer provides.
timeline.author: triceo

+ * For example: use {@code @JsonbTypeSerializer(HardSoftScoreJsonbSerializer.class) @JsonbTypeDeserializer(HardSoftScoreJsonbDeserializer.class)} + * on a {@code HardSoftScore score} field and it will marshalled to JSON as {@code "score":"-999hard/-999soft"}. + * @see Score + * @param the actual score type + */ +public abstract class AbstractScoreJsonbDeserializer>

replies.bodyText: @triceo Hmm, good question. I did a quick POC with JsonbAdapter, and it worked just as well with less code. I'll do a refactor, good catch! The end goal of this is to integrate it in the quarkus-optaplanner extension, and de/serializers offer more customization. But it seems Adapters do the job just fine.
replies.author: cuijulian

replies.bodyText: I agree that, in some cases, the customization is required. Here, Score already has methods that convert to and from String, and therefore JsonbAdapter is just enough - with the extra benefit of eliminating some code.
replies.author: triceo

replies.bodyText: Refactored to use JsonbAdapter instead. Changes have been pushed.
replies.author: cuijulian

replies.bodyText:
For me, this is enough. I know the felix plugin does some sanity verifications. Most importantly, we don't have split packages.
OSGi and Jigsaw both just need a unique module ID. For OSGi it's called export-package, for JigSaw, I guess module ID.
Other additional features of OSGi, such as osgi-specific code for dynamic loading is not in our scope.

timeline.bodyText: I don't much like regexes in Java, as they become very hard to read. Did you consider using \Q no need to escape in here \E to reduce some of that escaping?
timeline.author: triceo

replies.bodyText: What do you mean by \Q no need to escape in here \E? Though I do agree that these Java regexes are very ugly, see another example in optaplanner-persistence-jaxb. This PR actually is consistent with that style, though we might as well overhaul all of them in a separate PR. @ge0ffrey WDYT?
replies.author: cuijulian

replies.bodyText: In a Java regex string, you can use \Q to start a sequence in which escaping is not necessary. \E ends that sequence.
replies.author: triceo

replies.bodyText: I see, yes that would be a lot cleaner. In any case, we would have to change this for all the other modules, so I'm going to hide behind scope creep for this PR.
replies.author: cuijulian

timeline.bodyText: Suggestion: instead of using a regex, consider parsing the JSON again and make sure it has the structure you're expecting it to. This will make sure the JSON is valid, without you having to deal with the actual JSON syntax.
timeline.author: triceo

replies.bodyText: Similar to my comment above, this is currently the practice in the other optaplanner modules. The mentioned overhaul would address this, but I don't see this regex json check as a blocker for this specific PR (not in scope imo).

replies.bodyText:
Any such changes must also be applied to the jacksons tests (and potentially jaxb and xstream), for consistency.


Not sure about reusing the OptaPlannerJsonbConfig here: on one hand the philosophy of HardSoftScoreJsonbAdapterTest etc is to test the adaptor (= binding) in isolation, as a unit test. On the other hand, we want everyone to use the OptaPlannerJsonbConfig. So I am fine either way, as long is 1) is adhered to, with a slight preference to status quo. For Julian's sake, if we do it, I suggest in a follow up PR?
replies.author: ge0ffrey

replies.bodyText: This is currently consistent with the Jackson tests, any refactors will have to be done in a separate PR on all existing modules like Jackson, Jaxb, etc. As Geoffrey mentioned in his comment below, these individual Score Adapter tests are not quite a duplicate of the OptaPlannerJsonbConfig test. The latter tests that the Config object (which contains all the Score Adapters) actually works when used on a Wrapper with multiple Score types.

timeline.bodyText:
For moment, I got confused that this test duplicates HardSoftScoreJsonbAdapterTest, but it doesn't.
The jackson version of this has 2 Scores, including a "generic Score", something not supported by JSON-B (which is fine).
Suggestion: Add a BendableScore too in this test (so it has 2 scores). Also add a BendableScore in the jackson version of this test (so it has 3 scores).
This does give us some extra test code coverage, to prove that bendables also work without explicit annotations :)
